{{Third-party|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox sports competition event | event = | competition = 2018 Science Olympiad National Tournament | governing_body = Science Olympiad | year = 2018 | type = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | venue = [[Colorado State University]] | location = [[Fort Collins, Colorado]] | date = 18 May - 19 May, 2018 | competitors = | nations = | teams = 120 (from [[List of states and territories of the United States|50 states]]) | win_label = | win_value = | prize_money = | website = [https://www.coloradscienceolympiad.org/2018nationals Website] | Top three teams (B/C) = | gold = {{flag|Ohio|name=OH}} – Solon M.S. '''(B)'''
{{flag|California|name=CA}} – Troy H.S. '''(C)'''https://source.colostate.edu/california-ohio-schools-take-top-honors-at-science-olympiad-national-tournament/ | silver = {{flag|Illinois|name=IL}} – Daniel Wright J.H.S. '''(B)'''
{{flag|Ohio|name=OH}} – Mason H.S. '''(C)''' | bronze = {{flag|New Jersey|name=NJ}} – Community M.S. '''(B)'''
{{flag|Pennsylvania|name=PA}} – Harriton H.S. '''(C)''' | champion = | men = | women = | team = | previous = [[2017 Science Olympiad National Tournament|Wright State 2017]] | next = Cornell 2019 }} The '''2018 Science Olympiad National Tournament''' was the 34th{{cite web|url=https://source.colostate.edu/may-the-best-teens-win-csu-hosts-2018-science-olympiad-national-tournament-may-18-19|title=May the best teens win: CSU hosts 2018 Science Olympiad National Tournament, May 18-19|date=14 May 2018|publisher=}} annual edition of the National [[Science Olympiad]] tournament, a competition in which 120 teams{{cite web|url=https://www.soinc.org/2018-national-tournament-info|title=2018 National Tournament - Science Olympiad|website=www.soinc.org}} (sixty middle school and sixty high school) from all fifty states and the [[District of Columbia]] compete in twenty three [[science]]-related events, in various fields of science, such as [[chemistry]], [[physics]], [[biology]], and [[geology]]. The tournament was hosted for the first time by [[Colorado State University]] in [[Fort Collins, Colorado]], with competitions being held around campus and the opening and closing ceremonies being held at the [[Moby Arena]]. Only one of the winners from [[2017 Science Olympiad National Tournament|last year's national competition]] at [[Wright State University]] were able to defend their titles; the defending champions were Daniel Wright Junior High School ([[Illinois|IL]]) and Troy High School ([[California|CA]]). Troy finished first to successfully defend their title, and Daniel Wright finished second. Solon Middle School ([[Ohio|OH]]) won the Division B tournament to win their eighth title, keeping them in second for most National championships.{{cite web|url=https://scioly.org/wiki/index.php/National_Tournament_Winners#By_National_Titles|title=National Tournament Winners - Science Olympiad Student Center Wiki|website=scioly.org}} ==Final results== {| class="wikitable" |style="text-align:center;" colspan=3|Division B Top Tenhttps://www.soinc.org/sites/default/files/uploaded_files/2018DivBFinalResults.pdf |- ! Position ! Team ! Score |- style="background:#ffd700; color:black" | 1 | {{flagicon|OH}} Solon M.S. '''(C)''' | 173 |- style="background:#c0c0c0; color:black" | 2 | {{flagicon|IL}} Daniel Wright J.H.S. '''(D)''' | 189 |- style="background:#cd7f32; color:black" | 3 | {{flagicon|NJ}} Community M.S. | 230 |- | 4 | {{flagicon|CA}} Kennedy M.S. | 248 |- | 5 | {{flagicon|PA}} Springhouse M.S. | 309 |- | 6 | {{flagicon|North Carolina}} Piedmont IB M.S. | 326 |- | 7 | {{flagicon|MI}} Meads Mill M.S. | 327 |- | 8 | {{flagicon|Texas}} Beckendorff J.H.S. | 335 |- | 9 | {{flagicon|CA}} Jeffrey Trail M.S. | 342 |- | 10 | {{flagicon|Virginia}} Longfellow M.S. | 348 |} {| class="wikitable" |style="text-align:center;" colspan=3|Division C Top Tenhttps://www.soinc.org/sites/default/files/uploaded_files/2018DivCFinalResults.pdf |- ! {{Infobox organization | name = Association for Student Conduct Administration | image = Association for Student Conduct Administration (logo).png | image_size = | abbreviation = ASCA | formation = {{start date|1987}} | founder = Donald D. Gehring | type = Educational association | headquarters = [[College Station, Texas]] | coords = {{coord|30.611746|-96.343411|display=inline,title}} | fields = [[Student affairs]], student conduct, [[conflict resolution]] | membership = 3400 | membership_year = 2018 | leader_title = Executive Director | leader_name = Jennifer Waller | leader_title2 = President | leader_name2 = Cathy Cocks | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | affiliations = | staff = 4 | staff_year = 2017 | mission = ASCA is the leading voice for student conduct administration. | website = {{URL|theasca.org}} | formerly = Association for Student Judicial Affairs (ASJA) <small>(1987-2008)</small> | footnotes = }}
The '''Association for Student Conduct Administration (ASCA)''' (formerly the '''Association for Student Judicial Affairs''') is the leading voice for [[student affairs|student conduct]] administration within [[higher education]], conflict resolution, law and [[public policy]] related to student conduct administration. ASCA also attracts members who work in higher education [[health education|prevention education]] and [[Title IX]] administrators in the [[United States of America|United States]]. Founded in 1987 ASCA has over 3,000 members at over 1,000 institutions.<ref>{{cite web|title=ASCA About Page|url=http://www.theasca.org/about_asca|website=Association for Student Conduct Administration|publisher=Association for Student Conduct Administration|accessdate=19 July 2015}}</ref> ASCA's headquarters reside on the campus of [[Texas A&M University]] in [[College Station, Texas]], with a satellite office on [[Dupont Circle]] in [[Washington, D.C.]]<ref>{{cite web|title=ASCA Contact Page|url=http://www.theasca.org/contact_us|website=Association for Student Conduct Administration|publisher=Administration for Student Conduct Administration|accessdate=19 July 2015}}</ref>
== Mission == The mission statement of ASCA is to support higher education professionals by providing education materials and resources, intentional professional development opportunities and a network of colleagues to facilitate best practices of student conduct administration and conflict resolution on college and university campuses.<ref>{{cite web|title=About ASCA|url=http://www.theasca.org/about_asca|website=Association for Student Conduct Administration|publisher=Association for Student Conduct Administration|accessdate=19 July 2015}}</ref>
== History == The creation of the Association for Student Judicial Affairs was spearheaded by Donald D. Gehring of the [[University of Louisville]] in conversations with colleagues at the [[Stetson University]] Law and Higher Education Conference. ASJA officially came to form in 1987 with the creation of a steering committee and funding support from Raymond Goldstone of the [[University of California, Los Angeles]].<ref>{{cite web|title=About ASCA|url=http://www.theasca.org/about_asca|website=Association for Student Conduct Administration|publisher=Association for Student Conduct Administration|accessdate=19 July 2015}}</ref>
ASJA held its first annual conference in 1989 and began the annual Donald D. Gehring Academy for Student Conduct Administration in 1993. In 2008, ASJA changed its name to the Association for Student Conduct Administration (ASCA).<ref>{{cite web|title=ASCA History|url=http://www.theasca.org/files/history%20for%20website.pdf|website=Association for Student Conduct Administration|publisher=Association for Student Conduct Administration|accessdate=19 July 2015}}</ref> In 2015, ASCA opened a satellite office in [[Washington, D.C.]], in collaboration with the [[American College Personnel Association]], to facilitate more interaction with other higher education professional associations and to assist public policy advocacy efforts.
==Professional development== ASCA produces several national professional development programs each year, including an annual conference, the Donald D. Gehring Academy for Student Conduct Administration, a [[Title IX]] and Sexual Misconduct Institute, as well as national collaborations with other professional associations such as [[NASPA - Student Affairs Administrators in Higher Education|NASPA]], the [[Association of Fraternity Advisors]], and the [[National Association for Campus Activities]].
==Structure and communities of practice== ASCA is organizationally divided into four geographic regions administered by regional chairs with each state having a state coordinator.<ref>{{cite web|title=ASCA Regions|url=http://www.theasca.org/coordinators|website=Association for Student Conduct Administration|publisher=Association for Student Conduct Administration|accessdate=22 July 2015}}</ref> The association sponsors committees and communities of practice on topics such as [[conflict resolution]], research, [[academic integrity]], [[Educational assessment|assessment]], [[community college]]s, [[fraternity]] and [[sorority]] life, [[public policy]] and legislative issues, [[mental health]], [[threat assessment]] and [[sexual assault]].<ref>{{cite web|title=ASCA Communities of Practice|url=http://www.theasca.org/comm_practice|website=Association for Student Conduct Administration|publisher=Association for Student Conduct Administration|accessdate=22 July 2015}}</ref>
==Advocacy efforts== After the release of the [[United States Department of Education|Department of Education]]'s [[Office for Civil Rights]] (OCR) "Dear Colleague Letter" discussing [[Title IX]] and campus [[sexual assault]] in April 2011, ASCA leadership and publications were frequently cited in the national media to discuss topics related to sexual assault response.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Grassgreen|first1=Allie|title=Tide Shifts on Title IX|url=https://www.insidehighered.com/news/2012/04/24/ocr-dear-colleague-letter-prompts-big-change-sexual-assault-hearings-unc|website=Inside Higher Ed|publisher=Inside Higher Ed|accessdate=22 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Grassgreen|first1=Allie|title=Deadlines for Campus Justice|url=https://www.insidehighered.com/news/2012/10/09/duke-eliminates-statute-limitations-sex-assault-cases-after-confusion-ocr|website=Inside Higher Ed|publisher=Inside Higher Ed|accessdate=22 July 2015}}</ref> ASCA has voiced support for the OCR-required [[preponderance of the evidence]] standard in campus sexual assault adjudications,<ref>{{cite web|title=ASCA 2014 White Paper: Student Conduct Administration & Title IX: Gold Standard Practices for Resolution of Allegations of Sexual Misconduct on College Campuses|url=http://www.theasca.org/Files/Publications/ASCA%202014%20White%20Paper.pdf|website=Association for Student Conduct Administration|publisher=Association for Student Conduct Administration|accessdate=22 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Bruell|first1=Alex|title=Combating Sexual Assault in Schools|url=http://www.dailyuw.com/features/article_ae1ac346-301b-11e5-a42b-877cd0e34842.html|website=The Daily|publisher=The Daily|accessdate=22 July 2015}}</ref> mandatory academic transcript notation for serious disciplinary matters,<ref>{{cite journal|title=Transcript notations can help institutions reduce foreseeable risk|journal=Student Affairs Today|date=September 2014|volume=17|issue=6|page=1|url=http://www.theasca.org/files/Publications/transcriptnotationsarticle_SAT_17_06.pdf|accessdate=22 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Valenti|first1=Jessica|title=College rapists should not be able to transfer schools to skip consequences|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/apr/29/college-rapists-should-not-be-able-to-transfer-schools-to-skip-consequences|accessdate=22 July 2015|agency=The Guardian|date=29 April 2015}}</ref> and advocacy for institutionally-based discipline processes.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McMurtrie|first1=Beth|title=With Fraternities Under Scrutiny, Greek Lobbyists Take to Capitol Hill|url=http://chronicle.com/article/With-Fraternities-Under/229749/|accessdate=22 July 2015|agency=The Chronicle of Higher Education|date=29 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Bennett|first1=Laura|title=When the Student Culture Changes|url=http://chronicle.com/article/Sexual-Assault-on-Campus-9/229279/|accessdate=22 July 2015|agency=The Chronicle of Higher Education|date=April 2015}}</ref>
ASCA has received criticism from popular media outlets [[Huffington Post]] and [[Jezebel (website)|Jezebel]] for a perceived focus on educational outcomes in campus sexual assault adjudication.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kingkade|first1=Tyler|title=Many Universities Don't Want You To Know How They Punish Sexual Assault|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/29/punish-sexual-assault_n_5894856.html|accessdate=22 July 2015|agency=The Huffington Post|date=29 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Beusman|first1=Callie|title=Colleges Rarely Expel Students Found Responsible for Sexual Assault|url=http://jezebel.com/colleges-rarely-expel-students-found-responsible-for-se-1640310795|accessdate=22 July 2015|agency=Jezebel|publisher=Gawker Media|date=29 September 2014}}</ref> ASCA responded to those concerns with the publication of a "Gold Standard" report on sexual assault adjudication practices.<ref>{{cite web|title=ASCA 2014 White Paper: Student Conduct Administration & Title IX: Gold Standard Practices for Resolution of Allegations of Sexual Misconduct on College Campuses|url=http://www.theasca.org/Files/Publications/ASCA%202014%20White%20Paper.pdf|website=Association for Student Conduct Administration|publisher=Association for Student Conduct Administration|accessdate=22 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Hamlin|first1=Kelsey|title=Office for Civil Rights investigates UW for handling of sexual assault cases|url=http://www.dailyuw.com/news/article_1d571e74-1a25-11e5-b973-13257c4e7278.html|accessdate=22 July 2015|agency=The Daily|date=23 June 2015}}</ref>
==Foundation== The Raymond Goldstone ASCA Foundation provides funds for scholarships to ASCA professional development opportunities such as the annual conference or Gehring Academy.<ref>{{cite web|title=ASCA Goldstone Foundation|url=http://www.theasca.org/foundation|website=Association for Student Conduct Administration|publisher=Association for Student Conduct Administration|accessdate=22 July 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.theasca.org}}
{{Student Affairs Associations}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Association for Student Judicial Affairs}} [[Category:Educational organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1987]] [[Category:1987 establishments in Texas]] [[Category:Organizations based in Texas]] [[Category:Education-related professional associations]]
