List of proposed etymologies of OK

revision.comment: Alter: isbn, title, journal. Add: chapter-url, title-link. Removed accessdate with no specified URL. Removed parameters. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[User:Headbomb|Headbomb]]
revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of proposed etymologies of ''OK''}} This is a list of [[etymology|etymologies]] proposed for [[OK|the word ''OK'' or ''okay'']]. The majority can be easily classified as [[false etymology|false etymologies]], or possibly [[folk etymology|folk etymologies]]. [[H. L. Mencken]], in ''[[The American Language]]'', lists serious candidates and "a few of the more picturesque or preposterous".<ref name="mencken1945"> {{cite book |last=Mencken |first=Henry Louis |title=The American Language : Supplement I |chapterurl=https://archive.org/stream/americanlangu00menc#page/269/mode/2up |publisher=[[Alfred A. Knopf]] |location=New York City |year=1960 |orig-year=1945 |pages=269–279 : 275–276 |chapter=IV: The Period of Growth; 2. The expanding vocabulary |registration=Y |accessdate=28 February 2018}} </ref> [[Allen Walker Read]] surveyed a variety of explanations in a 1964 article titled ''The Folklore of "O. K."''<ref>Read February 1964</ref> [[Eric Partridge]] described O.K. as "an evergreen of the correspondence column."<ref>{{cite book |last=Partridge |first=Eric |title=A Dictionary of Slang and Unconventional English |year=1984| edition=8th| page=1373| isbn=978-0-7100-9820-7 |origyear=1937}}</ref>
{|class="wikitable sortable" |- ! {{midsize|Source language}} ! Source ! Context ! Date first used ! Proposer ! Date proposed ! Notes |- |English |Initials of "oll korrect" |Coined during a fad for comical misspellings and abbreviations |{{sort|1839|by 1839}} | |{{sort|1839|by 1839}} | Documented by [[Allen Walker Read]] in 1964,<ref name="read-first"> {{cite journal |last=Read |first=Allen Walker |date=February 1963 |title=The First Stage in the History of "O. K." |journal=[[American Speech]] |volume= 38 |issue= 1 |pages=5–27 |doi=10.2307/453580 |jstor=453580 }} </ref> and subsequently widely accepted by dictionaries<ref name="oed"> {{cite book |title=Oxford English Dictionary |edition=3rd (draft) |date=June 2008 |chapter=OK, adj., int.<sup>1</sup>, n.<sup>2</sup>, and adv. |title-link=Oxford English Dictionary }} </ref> and etymologists. |- | English | Initials of "Old Kinderhook" | Nickname for [[Martin Van Buren]], from his birthplace in [[Kinderhook (village), New York|Kinderhook, New York]]; used as a slogan in the [[United States presidential election, 1840|1840 presidential election]] | {{sort|1840|by 1840}} | editor of the New York ''New Era'' | {{sort|1840|27 May 1840}} | Reinterpreted by supporters of rival [[William Henry Harrison]] as "Out of Kash", "Orful Kalamity", etc. Allen Walker Read suggests this exploited and reinforced the pre-existing "oll korrect" sense.<ref name="read-second"> {{cite journal |last=Read |first=Allen Walker |date=May 1963 |title=The Second Stage in the History of "O. K." |journal=[[American Speech]] |volume= 38 |issue= 2 |pages=83–102 |doi=10.2307/453285 |jstor=453285 }} </ref> |- | [[Choctaw language|Choctaw]] | {{lang|cho|oke}}, {{lang|cho|okeh}} ("it is") | [[American pioneer|Frontiersman]] trading with [[Choctaw]]s borrowed the word directly or via [[Mobilian Jargon]] | {{sort|1812|by 1812}} | William S. Wyman | {{sort|1885|August 1885}} | The form is a verbal [[suffix]] "indeed, contrary to your supposition" with modern spelling {{lang|cho|-okii}}.<ref name="oed"/> Wyman suggested Andrew Jackson had learnt "O.K." from Choctaw and introduced it in the East; others suggest an 18th-century origin.<ref>Read February 1964 pp.14–17</ref> |- | Choctaw | {{lang|cho|si Hoka}} ('meaning "that's me" or "that's what I said"') | Learned by [[Andrew Jackson]] from [[Pushmataha]] | {{sort|1812|by 1812}} | [[William H. Murray]] | 1931 | Pushmataha was a Choctaw chief who fought under Jackson at the [[Battle of New Orleans]] and the [[Battle of Horseshoe Bend (1814)|Battle of Horseshoe Bend]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Murray |first=William Henry |year=1931 |title=Pocahontas and Pushmataha: historical and biographical essays with personal sketches of other famous Indians, and notes on Oklahoma history |edition=2nd |publisher=Harlow |page=30}}; cited in Read February 1964 pp.15–16</ref> |- | [[Wolof language|Wolof]] | {{lang|wo|waw-kay}} ({{lang|wo|waw}} "yes" + emphatic {{lang|wo|-kay}}) | Introduced by [[Slavery in the United States|West African slaves]] | {{sort|1815|by 1815}} | David Dalby | 1969 | First proposed in the Hans Wolff Memorial Lecture.<ref name="Cassidy"> {{cite journal |last=Cassidy |first=Frederic G. |date=Winter 1981 |title=OK. Is It African? |journal=[[American Speech]] |volume= 56 |issue= 4 (W) |pages=269–273 |doi=10.2307/455123 |jstor=455123 }} </ref> Dalby did not specify Wolof, suggesting also [[Mandinka language|Mandinka]] {{lang|mnk|o ke}} ("that's it", "certainly"; also "do it").<ref name="Cassidy"/> [[Liberia]]n Charles Blooah had noted the similarity of [[Jabo language|Jabo]] affirmative {{lang|grj|O'-ke}} in 1937 without asserting any causality.<ref name="Read1964p13">Read February 1964 p.13</ref> |- | English | Initials of "oll korrect" | Coined by humorist [[Josh Billings]] | {{sort|1860|1860s or 1870s}} | {{midsize|"Callisthenes"}} | {{sort|1935|1935}} | Proposed in an advertisement in ''[[The Times]]'' for [[Selfridges]]; "[[Harry Gordon Selfridge|Mr. Selfridge]]" purportedly remembered having read Billings as a boy.<ref>{{cite news |author="Callisthenes" |title=The Origin Of "O.K." |date=March 30, 1935 |issue=47026 |work=[[The Times]] |page=12; col A}} </ref> |- | English | Initials of "oll korrect" | Misspelling by [[Andrew Jackson]] | {{sort|1830|c.1830}} | [[James Gordon Bennett, Sr.]] | {{sort|1840|30 March 1840}} | Bennett's story, a fabricated propaganda set "a few years ago", is the first attribution of "O.K." to Jackson,<ref name="Read1964p13"/> although the quality of Jackson's spelling had already been debated during the [[United States presidential election, 1828|1828 presidential election]].<ref name="read-jackson"> {{cite journal |last=Read |first=Allen Walker |date=October 1963 |title=Could Andrew Jackson Spell? |journal=[[American Speech]] |volume= 38 |issue= 3 |pages=188–195 |doi=10.2307/454098 |jstor=454098}}</ref> [[Charles Godfrey Leland]] claimed in 1889 to have heard the Jackson-misspelling story in 1835.<ref>{{cite book |last=Leland |first=Charles G. |title=The Breitmann ballads |chapter-url=https://archive.org/stream/breitmannballads00lelarich#page/137/mode/1up |edition=New |series=The Lotos Series |year=1889 |publisher=Trübner |location=London |page=137, fn† |chapter=Breitmann in Politics |id= [[Open Library|OLID]] [https://openlibrary.org/books/OL7148389M OL7148389M]}}</ref> |- | English | Initials of "oll korrect" | Misspelling by Thomas Daniels | {{sort|1840|15 September 1840}} | | | Daniels painted a banner reading "The people is Oll Korrect" displayed at a rally for [[William Henry Harrison]] in [[Urbana, Illinois]]. H. L. Mencken described this as "the story generally credited" as the origin until earlier uses were discovered in the 1930s.<ref name="mencken1936">{{cite book |chapterurl=https://archive.org/stream/in.ernet.dli.2015.212093/2015.212093.The-American#page/n217 |title=The American Language |last=Mencken |first=Henry Louis |year=1949 |publisher=Alfred A. Knopf |location=New York City |pages=205–207 |chapter=V: The Language Today; 4: Other parts of speech |accessdate=19 February 2018 |edition=4th |orig-year=1936 |registration=Y}}</ref> Daniel Leffel, owner of the Sugar Grove tavern on the [[National Road]] outside [[Springfield, Ohio]], erected a prominent "O.K." sign after reading about Daniels' banner.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Keifer|first=J. Warren|title=O. K.|journal=Ohio Archæological and Historical Publications|volume=XIII|pages=350–354 : 352|url=https://archive.org/stream/ohioarchologicalohio#page/352 |accessdate=23 March 2018 |date=1904 }}</ref> |- | English | Initials of "oll korrect" | Misspelling by [[John Jacob Astor]] | {{sort|1800|c.1800}} | Eliezer Edward | {{sort|1881|1881}} | <ref>Read February 1964 p.13</ref> |- | English | Initials of "oll korrect" | Popularized by James Pyle based on Andrew Jackson usage | {{sort|1862|1862}} | ''New York Times'' obituary | {{sort|1900|1900}} | James Pyle, inventor of "Pyle's Pearline" purchased by Procter & Gamble in 1914 and renamed "Ivory Snow," placed an ad in the ''New York Times,'' October 23, 1862 which refers to James Pyle's O.K. Soap. The ''New York Times'' obituary of James Pyle dated January 21, 1900 says "Brought O.K. Into Popularity." The obituary states "He was the first to utilize in advertisements the letters OK in their business significance of all correct. He had the original use of these letters by Stonewall Jackson as an endorsement and was struck by their [[catchiness]]. By his extensive employment of them he probably did more than any other person to raise them to the dignity of a popular term and an established business institution." |- | English | Misspelling of "O.R." for "Order Received" | A common mistake in the Western U.S. owing to the similar shapes of the letters R and K. | {{sort|1790|by 1790}} | [[Albigence Waldo Putnam]] | {{sort|1859|1859}} | The 1790 bill of sale "Andrew Jackson, Esq., proved a bill of sale from Hugh McGary to Gasper Mansker for a negro man, which was O.K." is cited in Putnam's ''History of Middle Tennessee''; the assertion that the misspelling is common is added in [[James Parton]]'s 1860 ''Life of Andrew Jackson''. Woodford Heflin in 1939 established that the 1790 bill did in fact read "O.R." rather than "O.K." <ref>Read February 1964 pp.9–11</ref> |- | [[German language|German]] | Initials of {{lang|de|ohne Korrektur}} (without correction) | | {{sort|1900|c. 1900}} | Guido Carreras | {{sort|1941|June 30, 1941}} | In ''[[Newsweek]].''<ref>Read February 1964 p.20, fn.60</ref> |- | English | Initials of "O'Kelly" or "Obe<!-- sic-->diah Kelly" | An [[History of rail transport in the United States|early railroad]] agent or engineer certifying bills or deliveries. | | | {{sort|1933|by 1933}} |<ref>Read February 1964 p.19</ref> |- | German | Initials of {{lang|de|Otto Kaiser}} | An industrialist certifying his factory's produce for shipping | | | {{sort|1953|by 1953}} | Reported in 1953 to be widely believed in Germany.<ref>Read February 1964 p.21</ref> |- | [[Greek language|Greek]] | Initials of {{lang|el| Ὅλα Καλά}} ({{lang|el-Latn|Ola Kala}}, "everything is fine") | Used by Greek teachers marking students' work. Prominence of [[Greek shipping]] would allow it to be spread by sailors | | John Alfred Huybers | {{sort|1913|1913}} | In the editor's preface to '' When I was a boy in Greece'', by George Demetrios.<ref>Read February 1964 p.20, fn.79</ref><ref> {{cite journal |last=Weber |first=Robert |date=April 1942 |title=A Greek O. K. |journal=[[American Speech]] |volume= 17 |issue=2, Part 1 |pages=127–128 |jstor=486460}}</ref> [[Louise Pound]] supported the theory for a time.<ref>Read February 1964 p.20</ref> |- | [[Greek language|Greek]] | Initials of {{lang|el| Ὅλα Καλά}} ({{lang|el-Latn|Ola Kala}}, "everything is well"). | An abbreviation used by Greek immigrants in United States in the late 1800s, when sending telegrams to their relatives in Greece to keep the cost low. |late 19th century | | | |- | [[Greek language|Greek]] | {{lang|el-Latn|och, och}} ({{lang|el|ὤχ, ὤχ}}) | A magical incantation against fleas | {{sort|0920|c.920}} | W. Snow | {{sort|1939|26 October 1939<!--sic: 1935 in Mencken is a mistake-->}} | {{lang|el|ὤχ, ὤχ}} occurs in the ''[[Geoponica]]'', 13.15.9. Suggested in a letter to ''[[The Times]]''.<ref name="mencken1945"/><ref>{{cite news |first=W. |last=Snow |title=Points from Letters — O.K. |date=October 26, 1939 |issue=48446 |work=[[The Times]] |page=6; col. D}}</ref> |- | [[French language|French]] | {{lang|fr|au(x) quai(s)}} ("to the dock(s)") | Said of cotton bales accepted for export from [[New Orleans]] | {{sort|1803|by 1803}} | | {{sort|1961|by 1961}} | Martin R. Wall wrote in 1963 that he had been told this in France "several years ago".<ref name="Read1964p22">Read February 1964 p.22</ref> |- | [[French language|French]] | {{lang|fr|au(x) quai(s)}} ("on the quay(s)") | stencilled on [[Puerto Rican rum]] specially selected for export | | | {{sort|1953|before 1953}} | A conflation of the {{lang|fr|au quai}} and {{lang|fr|Aux Cayes}} theories.<ref name="Read1964p22"/> |- | [[French language|French]] | {{lang|fr|au(x) quai(s)}} ("on the quay(s)") | In the [[American Revolutionary War]], of French sailors making appointments with American girls | {{sort|1780|1780s}} | <small>"Beachcomber"</small> | {{sort|1940|28 June 1940}} | In the ''[[Daily Express]].''<ref name="mencken1945"/> |- | [[French language|French]] | {{lang|fr|Aux Cayes}} ("from {{lang|fr|[[Les Cayes]]|italic=no}}, [[Haiti]]") | {{lang|fr|Les Cayes|italic=no}} is a port from which high-quality [[rum]] was exported | | | {{sort|1905|by 1905}} | <ref>Read February 1964 pp.17–18</ref> |- | [[German language|German]] | Initials of {{lang|de|Ober Kommando}} (High Command) | Used by [[Friedrich Wilhelm von Steuben]], [[inspector general]] of the [[Continental Army]] the [[American Revolutionary War]] endorsing letters and orders | {{sort|1780|1780s}} | | {{sort|1938|23 January 1938}} | German article reprinted in the Omaha ''Tribune''.<ref name="mencken1945"/><ref>Read February 1964 p.21, fn.84</ref> Giving a similar story in a letter to ''The Times'' in 1939, Sir Anthony Palmer used the name "General Schliessen" and phrase ''[[Oberst]] Kommandant'' ("colonel in command").<ref name="mencken1945"/><ref>Read February 1964 p.21, fn.85</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Sir Anthony |last=Palmer |title=Points from Letters — O.K. |date=October 28, 1939 |issue=48448 |work=[[The Times]]|page=4; col. C}}</ref> |- | English | Initials of "Open Key" | A global [[telegraph]] signal meaning "ready to transmit" | {{sort|1861|"1861 or 1862"}} | | {{sort|1882|By 1882}}<ref>Read February 1964 p.14</ref> | The telegraph was not invented until 1844. A contemporary news report of the [[1866 transatlantic telegraph cable]] says "The following telegram has been received from Mr. R. A. Glass, Managing Director of the Telegraph Construction and Maintenance Company (Limited) :— 'O.K.,' (all correct)."<ref>{{cite newspaper |newspaper=Saunders's News Letter |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0001057/18660728/024/0003 |location=Dublin |title=The Atlantic Cable. First Direct Message. |page=3 |date=28 July 1866 |publisher=[[British Newspaper Archive]] |subscription=Y }}; cited in {{cite journal |journal=[[Notes & Queries]] |date=18 August 1866 |volume=X (3rd series) |number=242 |page=128 |title=Queries with Answers; O. K. |url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?q1=o.k.;id=uc1.l0063754345;view=image;seq=162;start=1;sz=10;page=root;num=128;size=100;orient=0 |accessdate=1 March 2018 |author="Achende" }}</ref> |- | [[Finnish language|Finnish]] | {{lang|fi|oikea}} ("correct") | | | | {{sort|1940|July 1940}} | In [[Cleveland]] Public Library ''Main Library News Notes.''<ref name="mencken1945"/> |- | English | Initials of [[Richard William Alan Onslow, 5th Earl of Onslow|Onslow]] and [[Hugh Godley, 2nd Baron Kilbracken|Kilbracken]] | On [[bill (proposed law)|bill]]s reviewed by the [[Lord Chairman of Committees]] of the [[House of Lords]] (Onslow) and his counsel (Kilbracken) | {{sort|1932|(after 1932)}} | [[John Raymond Godley, 3rd Baron Kilbracken|John Godley]] | 1939 | A jocular proposal by Kilbracken's son, then a student, in a letter to ''[[The Times]]'' in response to Sir Anthony Palmer's earlier letter.<ref name="mencken1945"/><ref> {{cite news |title=O.K. |last=Godley |first=John |date=November 2, 1939 |issue=48452 |work=[[The Times]] |page=9; col F}} </ref> |- | [[Latin]] | Initials of {{lang|la|Omnis Korrecta}} ("all correct") | Used by early schoolmasters marking examination papers | | | {{sort|1935|1935}} | In a letter in ''[[The Vancouver Sun]].''<ref>Read February 1964 p.20, fn.83</ref> |- | English | Initials of "outer [[keel]]" | Each timber in a wooden-[[Hull (watercraft)|hull]]ed ship would be marked; "O.K. No 1" was the first timber to be laid | | John D. Forbes | {{sort|1936|by 1936}} | <ref name="mencken1936"/> |- | English | ''hoacky'' or ''horkey'' | Name for the [[harvest festival]] in eastern England | | Wilfred White | {{sort|1935|7 March 1935}} | Suggested in an article in the ''[[Daily Telegraph]]''.<ref>Read February 1964 p.24, fn.100</ref> The phrase "hocky cry" is attested from 1555.<ref> {{cite book |title=Oxford English Dictionary |edition=2nd |chapter=hockey<sup>1</sup>, hawkey, horkey |title-link=Oxford English Dictionary }} </ref> |- | English | Initials of Orrin Kendall | Suppliers of high-quality biscuits to the [[United States Department of War|Union War Department]] during the [[American Civil War]]. | {{sort|1861|(after 1861)}} | | {{sort|1910|16 December 1910}} | Article in the [[Chicago Record Herald]].<ref>Read February 1964 pp.18–19</ref> |- | [[Old English]] | {{lang|ang|hogfor}} {{midsize|("seaworthy")}} | Shortened to ''HG'', then pronounced by Norwegian and Danish sailors as ''hah gay''. | | Frank Colby | {{sort|1943|21 March 1943}} | Colby reported the theory in his syndicated column "Take My Word For It", but did not endorse it.<ref name="mencken1945"/> |- | English | Initials of 0K "Zero Killed" | In military dispatches after a battle or combat mission in which no casualties had been suffered | | Leon Godchaux | {{sort|1981|2 March 1981}} | In a letter to ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''. |- | English | Initials of [[King's Observatory]], [[Kew]] | Stamped on timepieces and instruments certified by the Observatory | {{sort|1878|1878}} | Lorah Harris Graham<ref name="Graham1950">{{cite book|last=Graham|first=Lorah Harris|title=Inspirations: Radio Talks and Travel Sketches|year=1950|publisher=Ringgold Bible Club|page=29|quote=The Observatory of Kew sets the time for the world. If one's watch is set by that it is marked "O.K." — has been passed by the Observatory Kew. Hence, anything that is correct is "O.K." }}</ref> | {{sort|1950|1950}} | In fact, the stamp was "KO" rather than "OK",<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kingsobservatory.co.uk/resources/02_history/Cloake%20Study/Kings%20Observatory%20-%20Historical%20Report%20by%20John%20Cloake%20-%20Vol%201.pdf#page=17 |title=6. The work of the Observatory for scientific purposes 1842–1980; [b] The Royal Society 1871–1899 |last=Cloake |first=John |work=The King's Observatory: Historical Report |quote=The standardisation and verification work increased considerably in the 1870s and in 1877 the famous ’KO’ mark was agreed (to be introduced the following year) to brand instruments which had been tested and approved at the Kew Observatory. |accessdate=14 August 2015 }}</ref><ref name="Walker2011">{{cite book |last=Walker |first=Malcolm |title=History of the Meteorological Office |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O6jAo4m4L_gC&pg=PA172 |accessdate=14 August 2015 |date=14 November 2011 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=9781139504485 |page=172, esp. fig.7.5}}</ref> although the actual symbol comprised an ornate "O" and "K" superimposed,<ref name="Walker2011"/> and it was described as "OK" in an 1884 almanac.<ref>{{cite book |title=The British Almanac |edition=57th |year=1884 |publisher=Stationers' Company |page=Companion, Part 1, p.17 |nopp=Y |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=m6AFAAAAQAAJ&pg=RA1-PA17 |quote=All instruments so verified will leave Kew with a certificate, the Kew Observatory letters OK as a monogram, and a registered number.}}</ref> |- | [[Occitan language|Occitan]] | {{lang|oc|oc}} ("yes") | Introduced by colonists in [[Louisiana (New France)|French Louisiana]] | | F. R. H. McLellan | {{sort|1953|14 December 1953}} | In ''[[The Daily Telegraph]].''<ref>Read February 1964 p.23, fn.91</ref> |- | [[Scots language|Scots]] | {{lang|sco|och aye}} ("ah, yes") | [[Scottish American|Scottish immigrants to North America]] | | "Barbarian" | {{sort|1933|15 October 1933}} | In a letter in ''[[The Observer]].''<ref>Read February 1964 p.23 fn.98</ref> |- | [[Ulster Scots dialects|Ulster Scots]] | {{lang|sco|och aye}} ("ah, yes") | Brought by [[Scotch-Irish American|Scotch-Irish American immigrants]] | {{sort|1800|"18th [or] early 19th" century}} | Mary Degges | {{sort|1975|October 1975}} | A variant of the "och, aye" theory Degges heard in [[Belfast]]; the Ulster pronunciation is purportedly closer to "OK" that the Scottish equivalent.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Greco |first=Frank A. |year=1975 |title=The etymology of OK again: 2 |journal=American Speech |volume=50 |issue=3/4 |pages=334–335 |jstor=3088024 |doi=10.2307/3088024 |last2=Degges |first2=Mary }}</ref> |- | [[French language|French]] | {{lang|fr|O qu'oui}} ("ah, yes") | Emphatic form of "yes" | {{sort|1768|by 1768}} | William McDevitt<ref name="mencken1945"/> | {{sort|1945|by 1945}} | {{lang|fr|O qu'oui}} occurs in ''[[A Sentimental Journey Through France and Italy]]'' by [[Laurence Sterne]]. |- | English | Initials of "Old [[Keokuk (Sauk chief)|Keokuk]]" | The [[Sac (people)|Sac]] chief signed treaties with these initials | {{sort|1830|by 1830}} | | {{sort|1890|by 1890}} | The theory was mentioned but not endorsed by the ''[[Century Dictionary]]'' in 1890.<ref>Read February 1964 p.17</ref><ref>{{cite book|editor-last=Whitney|editor-first=William Dwight |editorlink=William Dwight Whitney|title=Century Dictionary|chapter-url=https://archive.org/stream/centurydictipt1400whituoft#page/4099/mode/1up|volume=Vol. 4, Part 14|year=1890|publisher=Century |location=New York|page=4099|chapter=O.K.}}</ref> |- | French | Misspelled initials of {{lang|fr|au courant}} | In a poem by "Hans Breitmann", semi-educated German immigrant created by humorist [[Charles Godfrey Leland]] | {{sort|1865|by 1865}} | | {{sort|1868|1868}} | Breitmann's poems appeared during the U.S. Civil War; the glossary to the 1868 British edition equates "O.K." with {{lang|fr|au courant}}.<ref name="Leland1868">{{cite book|last=Leland|first=Charles Godfrey|title=Hans Breitmann as a politician|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8v4yAQAAIAAJ&pg=RA1-PA71|accessdate=31 July 2012|edition=English |year=1868|publisher=Trübner & co.|location=London|page=71|chapter=Glossary}}</ref> |- | English | Opposite of KO "[[knockout]]" | | | | {{sort|1982|by 1981}} | Cited by [[Allan Pease]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Pease|first=Allan |title=Body Language: How To Read Others Thoughts By Their Gestures |chapterurl=https://archive.org/stream/BodyLanguageHowToReadOthersThoughtsByTheirGestures_201403/Body%20Language%20How%20To%20Read%20Others%20Thoughts%20By%20Their%20Gestures#page/n11/mode/1up|date=1988 |orig-year=1981|publisher=Sheldon Press|location=London|isbn=978-0-85969-406-3|page=11|chapter=A Framework for Understanding; The Ring or 'OK' Gesture |quote=There' are many different views about what the initials 'OK' stand for, some believing it stood for 'all correct' which may have been misspelled as 'oll korrect', while others say that it means the opposite of 'knock-out' that is, K.O. }}</ref> |}
==References== ===Sources=== * {{cite book |last=Metcalf |first=Allan |title=OK: The Improbable Story of America's Greatest Word |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=mPhj9DIXCWAC&pg=PA80 |date=9 November 2010 |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=9780199752522 |pages=80–95 |chapter=Chapter 6: False Origins}} * {{cite journal |last=Read |first=Allen Walker |date=February 1964 |title=The Folklore of "O. K." |journal=[[American Speech]] |volume= 39 |issue= 1 |pages=5–25 |doi=10.2307/453922 |jstor=453922}}

revision.text:
{{for|the German theologian|Martin Petzoldt}} '''Martin Petzold''' (born 1955) is a German classical [[tenor]] who performs in opera and in concert. A former member of the [[Thomanerchor]], he is particularly known for the part of the [[Evangelist (Bach)|Evangelist]] in oratorios and [[Passions (Bach)|Passions]] of [[Johann Sebastian Bach]].
== Career ==
Petzold was born in [[Leipzig]], the son of the theologian [[Ernst Petzold]]. He received his first musical education as a member of the [[Thomanerchor]],<ref name="bc" /> where he was a member from 1965 to 1974, at the same time as [[Georg Christoph Biller]]. His father, his brother and later his son Jakob were also choir members.
As Petzold initially refused to join the [[National People's Army|army]], the [[East Germany|East German]] authorities denied him the right to study music. He served for 18 months and then studied voice from 1979 to 1985 at the [[University of Music and Theatre Leipzig]] with Eva Schubert and Bernd Siegfried Weber.<ref name="bc" /> He wanted to sing in an opera chorus, but while still a student was engaged as a soloist in [[Halberstadt]] and [[Altenburg]]. In 1985 he became a member of the [[Landestheater Halle]].<ref name="bc" /> He appeared regularly at the [[Leipzig Opera]] from 1986, and has been a permanent member of the ensemble since 1988. He has sung the parts of David in Wagner's ''[[Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg]]'', Pedrillo in Mozart's ''[[Die Entführung aus dem Serail]]'', Toni in Henze's ''[[Elegie für junge Liebende]]'', Flaut in ''Ein Sommernachtstraum'' and Iwan in Shostakovich's ''[[Die Nase (opera)|Die Nase]]'', among others.<ref name="bc" /><ref name="trio" />
In concert, Petzold has collaborated with major orchestras and choirs, such as the Thomanerchor, the [[Dresdner Kreuzchor]], the [[Monteverdi-Chor Hamburg]], the [[Gewandhausorchester]], the [[MDR Symphony Orchestra]] and the [[Freiburg Baroque Orchestra]].<ref name="bc" /> A particular focus of his work is works by [[Johann Sebastian Bach]]; he has sung the part of the [[Evangelist (Bach)|Evangelist]] in his ''[[Christmas Oratorio]]'' and ''[[Passions (Bach)|Passions]]'', conducted by Biller, [[Peter Schreier]], [[Kurt Masur]], [[Roderich Kreile]], [[Rolf Schweizer]] and [[David Timm]].<ref name="bc" /> Petzold also works for the preservation of German folk songs.
In teaching, Martin Petzold has worked since 2002 as a lecturer at international master classes<ref name="bc" /> and is also a vocal coach of the Thomanerchor. In 2001, Martin Petzold was appointed [[Kammersänger]].<ref name="trio" /> <!-- In addition, he is making an increasing name for himself as an illustrator and cartoonist. -->
== References == {{reflist | refs =
<ref name="bc"> {{cite web | url = http://www.bach-cantatas.com/Bio/Petzold-Martin.htm | title = Martin Petzold (Tenor) | publisher = bach-cantatas.com | accessdate = 10 August 2012 }} </ref>
<ref name="trio"> {{cite web | url = http://www.st-koenig.de/proginfo/TrioMartin.html | title = Vita Martin Petzold | publisher = st-koenig.de | year = 2010 | language = German | accessdate = 15 August 2012 }} </ref>
}}
== External links ==
* {{DNB portal|123877660}} * [http://www.martinpetzold.com/ Martin Petzold] website
{{Authority control}}

{{Infobox school | name = Mësonjëtorja e Parë Shqipe | image = Korca 312.jpg | image_size = 250px | alt = | caption = Courtyard of the Mësonjëtorja museum, Korçë | motto = | motto_translation = | location = Shën Gjergji Boulevard, [[Korçë]] | country = [[Albania]], <small>then ([[Ottoman Empire]])</small> | coordinates = {{coord|40.6168|20.7799|format=dms|display=inline<!--,title-->}} | other_name = Mësonjëtorja | former_name = | type = | established = {{Start date|1887|3|7|df=y}} | closed = 1967 | district = | grades = | superintendent = | principal = | staff = | faculty = | gender = <!-- use | gender_label = to override the default label --> | age_range = <!-- or | lower_age = and | upper_age = --> | enrollment = <!-- or | enrolment = --> | campus_size = | campus_type = | team_name = | newspaper = | colors = <!-- or | colours = --> | communities = | feeders = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | footnotes = }}
'''Mësonjëtorja''' or '''The Albanian School''' was the first secular school in the [[Albanian language]] within [[Ottoman Albania]].<ref name="Sultana26"/> It was opened in [[Korçë]] during the late Ottoman period.<ref name=Palairet115/><ref name="Sultana26"/> The school building serves as a museum<ref name=Palairet115/> and is located on the north side of ''Bulevardi Shën Gjergji'' (St. George Boulevard).
The opening of the school was a result of the [[Albanian National Awakening|Albanian National Movement]] which aimed to create an independent Albania and to secure denied rights to [[Albanian people]] within the [[Ottoman Empire]]. Among others Mësonjëtorja was an important center of cultural and patriotic education. The school's importance was raised because until then giving lessons in the Albanian language was done in private and secret due to Ottoman rule. The school opened its doors on 7 March 1887 and since then the day is celebrated by Albanians as the "Day of Teachers".
== History == [[File:Mesonjetorja1899.jpg|thumb|200px|left|Pupils of the "Mësonjëtorja" in 1899]] In 1885, [[Naim Frashëri]], a government civil servant in the education ministry, [[Sami Frashëri]] and along with other influential Albanians involved in the [[Society for the Publication of Albanian Writings]] managed to get permission from the sultan for the opening of a private Albanian boys elementary school in [[Korçë]].<ref name="Skendi134"/><ref name="Gawrych88"/><ref name=Ozdalga264265/> Financial support for the school came from a diaspora organisation [[Drita (magazine)|Drita]] ({{lang-en|the Light}}), an Albanian society based in [[Bucharest]], while Albanians from Istanbul got [[Pandeli Sotiri]] to become its first school director.<ref name="Skendi134"/><ref name="clayer">{{cite book|last=Clayer|first=Natalie|title=Aux origines du nationalisme albanais: la naissance d'une nation majoritairement musulmane en Europe|publisher=KARTHALA Editions|year=2007|pages=301–10|isbn=2-84586-816-2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=umotBF3KFWgC&pg=PA301|language=French}}</ref> Both the Society for Albanian Writings and Drita had agreed in past times not to antagonize town notables who were under Greek cultural influence by founding Albanian schools.<ref name="Skendi134"/> As such Drita sent one of its members [[Thimi Marko]], a town native on a mission to discuss the matter and he met with the Orthodox Metropolitan and his council (demogerontia) in Korçë.<ref name="Skendi134"/> The [[Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople|Constantinople Patriarchate]] refused have Albanian taught within existing Greek schools belonging to the Korçë Orthodox community.<ref name="Skendi134"/> Pandeli Sotiri was sent to Korçë and opened the school on 7 March 1887.<ref name="Skendi134">{{harvnb|Skendi|1967|p=134.}}</ref><ref name="Sultana26">{{harvnb|Sultana|2002|p=26.}}</ref><ref name="Gawrych88"/> Due to a lack of education material Sami, his brother [[Naim Frashëri]] and several other Albanians wrote textbooks in the Albanian language for the school.<ref name="Gawrych88"/> During 1887, Pandeli Sotiri had to leave Korçë and administration of the school passed to [[Petro Nini Luarasi]], a revolutionary and [[Thanas Sina]].<ref name="Skendi135"/> The Ottoman authorities gave permission only for Christian children to be educated in Albanian, but the Albanians did not follow this restriction and allowed Muslim children to attend.<ref name=Ozdalga264265/> In the first few years, the school overall had some two hundred enrolled students of Muslim and Christian faiths.<ref name="Gawrych88"/><ref name="Skendi134135">{{harvnb|Skendi|1967|pp=134-135.}}</ref> By 1888, the elementary school had 100 Christian and 60 Muslim students.<ref name="Gawrych88">{{harvnb|Gawrych|2006|p=88.}}</ref>
[[File:Korça Mësonjtorja.jpg|thumb|230px|right|The Mësonjëtorja in Korçë]] Local pressure against parents sending their children to the school grew.<ref name="Gawrych89"/> The Constantinople Patriarchate was opposed the school's establishment and along with mainly Greek clerics both were concerned that the development of a national consciousness among Orthodox Albanians could lead to the creation of an Orthodox Albanian church.<ref name="Gawrych89"/> As such from its founding the metropolitan and Orthodox notables intensified attacks against the school, while the school was denounced as subversive to Orthodox unity by local Greek priests.<ref name="Skendi135"/><ref name="Gawrych89"/> The Orthodox church threatened excommunication and forced parents to remove their children from attending the school resulting in a drastic drop of student numbers.<ref name="Skendi135"/> During the same time Muslims were discouraged from enrollment and forced by the local Ottoman administration to withdraw attending the school as they feared that an Albanian national renaissance might eventuate in revolutionary activity.<ref name="Skendi135"/><ref name="Gawrych89"/> Over time due to pressure coming from both sides school enrollment went down to eighty students.<ref name="Gawrych89">{{harvnb|Gawrych|2006|p=89.}}</ref>
During the school's existence, the organisation Drita (later renamed as Dituria) and the Albanian Society of Istanbul viewed as one of their aims being to support the elementary school in Korçë.<ref name="Skendi146147">{{harvnb|Skendi|1967|pp=146-147.}}</ref> Financial difficulties however plagued the school as Albanians could not raise the needed funds to support it.<ref name="Skendi135">{{harvnb|Skendi|1967|p=135.}}</ref> The pro-Patriarchate party in Korçë falsely accused Albanians involved with the school of raising funds for [[Komitadji|Komita]] guerilla bands against Ottoman rule.<ref name="Skendi136"/> Support came from the people and school managed to survive for fifteen years.<ref name="Sultana27"/> Nuçi Naçi, had become the new director of the school and had managed to get support from the Turkish governor general based in Monastir (modern [[Bitola]]).<ref name="Skendi136"/> A translated version of Sami's play [[Sami Frashëri#The Besa yahut Ahde Vefa play|''Besa yahut Ahde Vefa'']] (Pledge of Honour or Loyalty to an Oath) in Albanian celebrating an Albanian identity also became part of the school curriculum in 1901.<ref name="Gawrych148"/> After a visit (1902) to Bucharest, [[Idhomene Kosturi]] told Albanians in Korçë that the main concern of Dituria was to improve the boys school through student attainment of higher grades, selecting better teachers and introducing new subjects.<ref name="Skendi146147"/> The mistrust of Christians by the sultan increased who thought that Albanian education could contribute to the concept of Albanian unity and nationality open to exploitation by foreign interests.<ref name="Skendi136"/> [[Abdul Hamid II]] ordered the school closed down in 1902.<ref name="Gawrych148">{{cite book|last=Gawrych|first=George|title=The Crescent and the Eagle: Ottoman rule, Islam and the Albanians, 1874–1913|year=2006|location=London|publisher=IB Tauris|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=wPOtzk-unJgC&printsec=frontcover&dq=The+crescent+and+the+eagle:+Ottoman+rule,+Islam+and+the+Albanians,+1874-1913+lexicon&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiT94zl8ebXAhWJT7wKHYRLADEQ6AEIJjAA#v=snippet&q=Then%20in%201886&f=false|isbn=9781845112875|pages=148.|ref=harv}}</ref> Mehmed Ali Pasha Delvina, the new Ottoman governor of Korçë supported the empire, was against Albanian nationalism and in 1902 Nuçi Naçi was arrested and incarcerated in Salonica.<ref name="Skendi136"/> The school had survived until 1902 under the teachers Leonidis and Naum Naça who were arrested and declared as traitors by Ottoman authorities at the request of Greek clergy with the school being closed down, vandalised and wrecked. <ref name="Sultana27">{{cite book|last=Sultana|first=Ronald G.|title=Teacher Education in the Euro-Mediterranean Region|year=2002|publisher=P. Lang|isbn=9780820462165|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=eD2dAAAAMAAJ&q=Mesonjetorja+shkolla&dq=Mesonjetorja+shkolla&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwifudHZzIDcAhWX7GEKHWnNCVEQ6AEIWDAH|pages=27.|ref=harv}} "Due to the support of the people, the Mësonjëtorja e parë shqipe managed to survive for fifteen years, till it was severely attacked by the Greek Orthodox church and the Ottoman government and was finally closed down in 1902.</ref><ref name=Palairet115/> By 1903 the school's trustees Vani Kosturi, [[Spiro Kosturi]], Thimi Marko and [[Orhan Pojani]] were also arrested and imprisoned in Salonica, while Pojani was exiled to [[Anatolia]].<ref name="Skendi136">{{cite book|last=Skendi|first=Stavro|title=The Albanian national awakening|year=1967|location=Princeton|publisher=Princeton University Press|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?hl=en&lr=&id=8QPWCgAAQBAJ&oi=fnd&pg=PR15&dq=The+Albanian+National+Awakening&ots=zGjQbVyql8&sig=xsmbL-yAAtc-ny3v0E4vN87JOBY&redir_esc=y#v=snippet&q=Albanian%20school%20for%20boys&f=false|isbn=9781400847761|pages=136.|ref=harv}}</ref>
Albanian efforts for an Albanian school are represented in Greek sources as a failure due to weak demand and limited funding, but Michael Palairet notes that Greek interference undermined the school.<ref name=Palairet115>{{cite book|last=Palairet|first=Michael|title=Macedonia: A Voyage through History (Vol. 2, From the Fifteenth Century to the Present)|year=2016|location=Cambridge|publisher=Cambridge Scholars Publishing|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=nyb5DAAAQBAJ&pg=PA114&dq=Kor%C3%A7%C3%AB+Vlachs+Greeks&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Kor%C3%A7%C3%AB%20Vlachs%20Greeks&f=false|isbn=9781443888493|pages=115|quote=Despite this, in 1884 the Albanian Committee set up a boys school. Greek sources represent Albanian efforts to compete in establishing schools as failing because of weaker demand for education and smaller funding, but once more, Greek interference undermined the school: it "struggled in the face of Greek anathemas". It is, however, the first Albanian school to be founded, and the building in Korçë (or a facsimile thereof) is preserved as a museum. It survived till 1902, under teachers Naum and Leonidas Natcha, but they were incarcerated as traitors (to the Ottoman state) at the behest of the Greek clergy, and their school was wrecked and vandalized. An American inspired Protestant school was founded, also at Korçë in 1889, but it struggled in the face of similar pressures.|ref=harv}}</ref><ref name=Ozdalga264265>{{cite book|last=Özdalga|first=Elisabeth|title=Late Ottoman Society: The Intellectual Legacy|year=2005|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9780415341646|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=LRMVn7D3QVMC&pg=PA260&dq=%C3%96zdalga+Naim+school&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiv2L3TxoDcAhWKfrwKHcgaDpoQ6AEIJzAA#v=onepage&q=%C3%96zdalga%20Naim%20school&f=false|pages=264–265|ref=harv}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Education in Albania]] *[[Albanian National Awakening]] *[[Albanian nationalism]] *[[Congress of Elbasan]] *[[Congress of Manastir]] *[[Second Congress of Manastir]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox artist | name = Olive Rush | image = Olive Rush.jpg | caption = Olive Rush, c. 1921 | birth_date = {{Birth date|1873|06|10}} | birth_place = Fairmount, Indiana | death_date = {{Death date and age|1966|08|20|1893|6|10}} | death_place = Santa Fe, New Mexico | resting_place = Park Cemetery, [[Fairmount, Indiana]] | nationality = American | alma_mater = Earlham College | known_for = Painting }} [[Image:Olive-Rush-Mural-NMSU-Biology-Bldg.jpg|250px|thumb|right|A portion of Olive Rush’s May 1936 [[Works Progress Administration|WPA]] mural at [[New Mexico State University|NMSU]].]] [[File:OliveRush1912.png|thumb|Olive Rush, from a 1912 publication.]] '''Olive Rush''' (June 10, 1873 near [[Fairmount, Indiana]] – August 20, 1966 in [[Santa Fe, New Mexico]]) was an illustrator, muralist, and an important pioneer in [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] [[art education]].
Today her paintings are held in a number of private collections and museums, including the [[Haan Mansion Museum of Indiana Art]].
==Education== Raised as a [[Society of Friends|Quaker]], Olive Rush studied at [[Earlham College]], the art school associated with the [[Corcoran Gallery of Art]] and at the [[Art Students League of New York|Art Students League]] before becoming an illustrator in New York.<ref>{{cite news|last=Abatemarco|first=Michael|title=A Hoosier in Santa Fe: Artist Olive Rush|work=McClatchy-Tribune Business News|publisher=Tribune Content Agency LLC|date=December 5, 2015|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1630391659|accessdate=March 7, 2015}}</ref> She was well known for her portraits and paintings of children and women, many of which were featured in magazines such as ''[[Woman's Home Companion]]'' and ''[[St. Nicholas Magazine|St. Nicholas]]''. In 1904 she moved to [[Wilmington, Delaware]], to study with [[Howard Pyle]], and she stayed until 1910. She spent the next year in Europe studying British and French painters, and finished her art education at the [[School of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston|Boston Museum School]] in 1912. In 1913 Rush returned to Europe with her friend, the watercolorist [[Alice Schille]], visiting Belgium and France.
==Career== In 1914 Rush, with her father, visited [[New Mexico]] and [[Arizona]], and she had a one-person exhibition at the [[Palace of the Governors]] in [[Santa Fe, New Mexico|Santa Fe]]. She made several visits to New Mexico over the next couple of years and moved permanently to Santa Fe in 1920. Despite the relative isolation of Santa Fe, Rush continued to contribute to national and international shows over the next thirty years, which activity culminated in a retrospective at the [[New Mexico Museum of Art|Museum of New Mexico Art Gallery]] in 1957.
Her former studio on Canyon Road in Santa Fe is now the home to the Santa Fe Quaker Meeting, as well as having guest house facilities available on the site.
Rush considered her major influences to be early Chinese art, Japanese art, and [[El Greco]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Rush|first=Olive|title=Olive Rush Paintings|year=1957|publisher=Museum of New Mexico Art Gallery|location=Santa Fe}}</ref> She was also inspired by the colorful style of [[Hopi]] and other Puebloan artists of the 1930s and 1940s.<ref>{{cite web|last=Booker|first=Margaret M.|title=Hopi|work=Grove Art Online|publisher=University Oxford Press|url=http://www.oxfordartonline.com/subscriber/article/grove/art/T038894|accessdate=March 7, 2015}}</ref>
==Murals== Murals were produced from 1934 to 1943 in the [[United States]] through the [[Section of Painting and Sculpture]], later called the [[Section of Fine Arts]], of the [[United States Department of the Treasury|Treasury Department]]. The murals were intended to boost the morale of the American people from the effects of [[Great Depression in the United States|the Depression]] by depicting uplifting subjects.<ref>[http://www.portal.state.pa.us/portal/server.pt/community/arts_and_architecture/2805/post_office_murals/432816 Rediscovering the People's Art: New Deal Murals in Pennsylvania’s Post Offices]". Pennsylvania Historical and Museum Commission: 2014.</ref> Almost 850 artists were commissioned to paint 1371 murals, most of which were installed in post offices, libraries, and other public buildings.<ref name="ark">University of Central Arkansas. "[http://uca.edu/postofficemurals/home/ Arkansas Post Office Murals]".</ref> 162 of the artists were women. The murals were funded as a part of the cost of the construction with 1% of the cost set aside for artistic enhancements.<ref name= "ark" />
Olive Rush was commissioned by the Section of Fine Arts to complete painted murals for several public buildings in the American West. In Santa Fe, New Mexico she completed ''The Library Reaches the People'', a fresco at the public library (now part of the [[New Mexico History Museum]]), as well as at the hotel [[La Fonda on the Plaza|La Fonda]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Broder|first1=Patricia|title=The American West : the modern vision|date=1984|publisher=Little, Brown, and Company|location=Boston|isbn=0821215787|page=230}}</ref> In [[Pawhuska, Oklahoma]] she completed an oil on canvas mural, ''Osage Treaties'' for the post office. In [[Florence, Colorado]] she painted ''Antelope'' for the post office. Lastly, she completed two frescos, ''Cotton Industry and Farming'' and ''Natural History of Plant and Animal Life'' for the Foster Hall Biology Building at [[New Mexico State University]]. Also, her mural for the Maisel's Trading Post on Central in Albuquerque is still in place. She taught mural painting to students at the Santa Fe Indian School, which is now the [[Institute of American Indian Arts]].
== Museum and gallery holdings == *Houston (MFA): ''The Huntress'' (c. 1938, watercolour) *Indianapolis (MA): ''Woman at Loom'' (c. 1907, oil on academy board); ''On the Balcony'' (oil on canvas) *Lincoln (Sheldon Memorial AG, University of Nebraska): ''Food Bearers'' (1923, oil on canvas) *New York (Brooklyn Mus.): ''Deer Path'' (watercolour) *Norman (Fred Jones Jr. MA, University of Oklahoma): ''The White Sands (with fox)'' (c. 1925, oil on panel) *Roswell (Mus. and Art Center): ''Weird Land'' (c. 1934); ''The Apple from the Sea Returning'' (c. 1935, watercolour) *Santa Fe (Mus. of New Mexico, MFA): collection of works, including ''After War - Frustration'' (oil); ''Indian Children at San Xavier'' (oil); ''Portrait of Mary Austin'' (c. 1933); ''Viaducts and Villages'' (c. 1950, watercolour) *Washington DC (Phillips Collection): ''On the Mesa'' (c. 1925, oil on cardboard); ''Charros at Rodeo'' (1929, watercolour on board) *Washington DC (Smithsonian American AM): Olive Rush papers, 1879-1967 *Wilmington (Delaware AM): ''Gazelle Grazing'' (oil); ''Interior of the Howard Pyle Studio'' (c. 1911, watercolour and pastel) *Worcester (AM): ''Edge of the Forest'' (c. 1928, watercolour); ''Fallow Deer'' (c. 1928, watercolour over graphite)<ref>"Rush, Olive" Oxford Art Online/Grove Dictionary of Art</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Resources== * Cuba, Stanley L. (1992) ''Olive Rush: A Hoosier Artist in New Mexico'', Minnetrista Cultural Foundation, Muncie, Indiana. {{ISBN|0-9623291-4-2}} * ''New York Sun'', March 17, 1933, p. 14. * [http://www.tfaoi.com/aa/5aa/5aa92.htm “Women Artists of Santa Fe” by Michael R. Grauer] * Newton, Judith Vale and Carol Ann Weiss. (2004) ''Skirting the Issue: Stories of Indiana's Historical Women Artists'', [[Indiana Historical Society]] Press, Indianapolis. {{ISBN|0-87195-177-0}}
==External links== *{{commonscat-inline}} *[http://www.aaa.si.edu/collectionsonline/rusholiv/ Olive Rush Papers Online at the Smithsonian Archives of American Art] *[http://santa-fe.quaker.org/ Santa Fe Friends (Quaker) Meeting at the Former Olive Rush Studio] *[http://sam.nmartmuseum.org/view/objects/asitem/People$004076/0?t:state:flow=f3600310-158e-498d-b73e-49b12d96ccf2/ Santa Fe Hillside at New Mexico Museum of Art] {{Authority control}}

{{Infobox architect |name= Peter Rose |image= |caption= |nationality= [[Canadians|Canadian]] |birth_place= [[Montreal]], Quebec, Canada |death_date= |death_place= |alma_mater= [[Yale University]] |practice= |significant_buildings= [[Canadian Centre for Architecture]] |significant_projects= |significant_design= |awards= }} '''Peter Rose''', is an [[architect]] and educator from [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], Canada. He is the principal of Peter Rose + Partners, an architectural practice based in [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]].
Rose's best-known work in Canada is the [[Canadian Centre for Architecture]] (CCA), which was designed by Rose with CCA founder [[Phyllis Lambert]] as consulting architect and [[Erol Argun]] as associate architect.<ref name="Wagg1">{{cite book|last=WAGG|first=SUSAN|title=Canadian Centre for Architecture/Centre Canadien d'Architecture|publisher=[[The Canadian Encyclopedia]]|url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/en/article/canadian-centre-for-architecturecentre-canadien-darchitecture/}}</ref> Completed in 1989, the CCA received the [[Honor Awards for Architecture|Honor Award for Architecture]] from the [[American Institute of Architects]] and the [[Governor General's Awards#Governor General's Medals in Architecture|Governor General's Medals in Architecture]] in 1992.<ref name="Wagg2">{{cite book|last=WAGG|first=SUSAN|title=Rose, Peter Douglas|publisher=The Canadian Encyclopedia|url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/en/article/peter-douglas-rose/}}</ref>
Rose founded the Alcan Lectures in Architecture, which ran from 1974 to 1992. This lecture series sponsored by [[Alcan Aluminium Limited]] brought architects, architectural historians and planners to the city. Rose's association with Alcan also included interior planning and design with [[Peter Lanken]] on the company's world headquarters [[Maison Alcan]] on [[Sherbrooke Street]], which preserved a row of historic buildings in city's [[Golden Square Mile]] district.<ref name="Wagg2"/>
In collaboration with [[Aurèle Cardinal]], Rose designed the plans for the redevelopment of the [[Old Port of Montreal]] in the early 90s.<ref>{{Citation | last = Affleck | first = Gavin | title = IN FULL VIEW: PUBLIC SPACE IN MONTREAL | newspaper = Canadian Architect | url =http://www.canadianarchitect.com/issues/ISarticle.asp?aid=1000219168&PC= }}.</ref>
After studying architecture at [[Yale University]], where he worked under [[Vincent Scully]] and [[Charles Willard Moore|Charles Moore]], Rose returned to Montreal, designing [[Postmodern architecture|Postmodern]] [[vacation house]]s in the [[Eastern Townships]] and [[Laurentides|Laurentian]] regions. He is noted for his residential designs for homes in western [[New England]], including several vacation cottages in northern Vermont and individual houses in [[Sharon, Connecticut]] and [[Stowe, Vermont]]. His design for the house in Stowe was selected as one of ''[[Architectural Record]]'''s Record Houses in 1998. The ''[[New York Times]]'' featured his renovation of a [[townhouse]] for [[Edgar Bronfman, Jr.]] in [[Manhattan]] in September 1999.<ref name="Wagg2"/><ref>William Morgan, [http://www.projo.com/opinion/contributors/content/CT_morgan2_02-02-10_FVH9FOK_v16.3f8daa3.html The unaccidental Rose bends annex at Kripalu Yoga], ''The Providence Journal'', February 2, 2010</ref>
In 2010, construction was completed on Rose's design for a dormitory at the [[Kripalu Center|Kripalu Center for Yoga and Health]] in [[Stockbridge, Massachusetts]].<ref>[[Robert Campbell (journalist)|Robert Campbell]], [http://www.boston.com/ae/theater_arts/articles/2010/05/09/new_dorm_at_kripalu_center_radiates_sustainability_and_simplicity/ Kripalu center dorm radiates simple sustainability], ''The Boston Globe'', May 9, 2010</ref>
Rose is adjunct professor of Architecture at the [[Harvard Graduate School of Design]] and has taught at [[Princeton University]], [[McGill University]] and the [[University of Toronto]]. He is the author of ''Peter Rose: Houses'', published by [[Princeton Architectural Press]].<ref name="papress">{{cite web|url=http://www.papress.com/html/book.details.page.tpl?isbn=9781568988214|title=Peter Rose: Houses |work=[[Princeton Architectural Press]]|accessdate=6 December 2009}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.5)
revision.text:
A '''pracademic''' is someone who is both an [[academic]] and an active practitioner in their subject area.
The term has a history of at least 30 years, but its first coining is unclear. The earliest reference may have been identified by a subscriber to Worldwide Words<ref>[http://www.worldwidewords.org/backissues/wbi080830.txt Worldwide Words] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090720080943/http://www.worldwidewords.org/backissues/wbi080830.txt |date=July 20, 2009 }}</ref> as being 1973.
In his 2001 Article 'The Life and Times of Pracademics', Paul L Posner <ref>[http://www.maxwell.syr.edu/pa/minnowbrook3/PDF%20Files/Phase%20II%20Papers/Posner%20-%20The%20Pracademic.pdf Article] {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> discusses the term pracademic. Since Posner's article many academics have used the term in journals and elsewhere.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mpa.niu.edu/pub_ad/publications/pracademic.shtml |accessdate=February 8, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828061229/http://www.mpa.niu.edu/pub_ad/publications/pracademic.shtml |archivedate=August 28, 2008 }}</ref> In 2001 Maria R Volpe and David Chandler in their paper in Negotiation Journal <ref>Maria R Volpe and David Chandler, Resolving and Managing conflicts in Academic Communities: The Emerging Role of the "Pracademic", Negotiation Journal, Vol 17 Iss 3, P245-255, 2001, Wiley InterScience</ref> describe the bridging role as that of the 'Pracademic'. Again in 2001 Willard T. Price uses the term in the same context of academic and practicing professional in Public Works.<ref>Willard T. Price, A Pracademic Research Agenda for Public Infrastructure, Public Works Management & Policy, Vol. 5, No. 4, 287-296 (2001), Sage</ref> George L Hanbury builds on the term in his paper on the ethics of honor by describing himself as a Pracademic and observing his subject from this stand point.<ref>George L. Hanbury, A “Pracademic’s” Perspective of Ethics and Honor: Imperatives for Public Service in the 21st Century!, Public Organization Review, Volume 4, Number 3, September 2004 , pp. 187-204, Springer</ref>
Although the core bridging concept appears to be the main theme several other usages have emerged. The idea of the Pracademic being a type of teaching style for [[Entrepreneur]]s has appeared in several places. A pracademic degree <ref>[http://www.dream-start.com/pracademic%20degree.htm Pracademic Degree] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080922063618/http://www.dream-start.com/pracademic%20degree.htm |date=2008-09-22 }}</ref> for instance describes the case of a new degree in the UK that is taught by practitioners to students who want to be entrepreneurs. However this use of the term remains close to the main definition of bridging the academic and practical professional world. Additionally many academics now describe themselves as Pracademics on their web sites and this use of the term aligns well with definition set out here. There may be other uses of the term.
In 2000 the term was used to describe Ross James, who conceptualised the Transitional Learning Model <ref>[https://books.google.com/books/about/The_Transitional_Learning_Model.html?id=ysoSAAAACAAJ The Transitional Learning Model: A Handbook for Training Design - Ross W. James - Google Books<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> following extensive research for his doctoral dissertation. The model integrated learning and cross-cultural theories into a practical model to help workplace trainers design and deliver training. The model has been applied in a wide range of workplace settings. Health Communication Resources <ref>[http://h-c-r.org/ Health Communication Resources<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> has used the model in its extensive international delivery of resources for training learner-centred trainers in international radio broadcast networks.
The term was first used in relation to the UK [[resilience (organizational)|resilience community]] at the inaugural conference of the Institute of Civil Protection and Emergency Management (April 2009).<ref>[http://www.icpem.net/Resources/Documentlinks/tabid/107/Default.aspx ICPEM | Institute of Civil Protection and Emergency Management | Document links<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Peter Simpson from the [[London Fire Brigade]], who undertook a Master’s programme at [[Leicester University]] as a mature student, described people like himself and others in the resilience community as ‘pracademics’ and showed delegates the ‘Pracademic Curve’, which clearly illustrated the inter-relationship between the practitioner and academic communities, particularly as it affects those who go into academia having already embarked on a career as a practitioner.
In 2008, the term was introduced in the Criminal Justice education arena, with a paper and presentation entitled The Pracademic and Academic in Criminal Justice Education at the Academy of Criminal Justice Sciences by Stephen A. Morreale of Worcester State University and James E. McCabe of Sacred Heart University. The paper focuses on the benefit of blending faculty that represent both the academic and pracademic perspectives, for the benefit of both the academic department and Criminal Justice students.
Many designers also have started taking interest in this term lately in their theories, research as well as practice. In 2008, Ahmedabad based architectural firm has named their office as studio prAcademics. Studio is led by Tejas Kathiriya providing architecture, interior design and urban design services. They are involved in merging the design theories with professional practice and vice versa.
In 2013, the term was introduced to the field of teacher education as well. Writing about teacher education practices in general, and teacher education in the Teaching of English to Speakers of Other Languages (TESOL) in particular, Jain <ref>Jain, R. (2013) Practitioner Research as Dissertation: Exploring the Continuities between Practice and Research in a Community College ESL Classroom. Ph.D. Dissertation, University of Maryland, College Park. Retrieved from http://hdl.handle.net/1903/14515.</ref> theorized about the relevance of the term to the lives of those who work on the intersections of practice and research. Jain used the term 'pracademic' to (re)imagine her professional identity as that comprising a coherent, albeit hybridized, unity--that of a practitioner as well as an academic.
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Education and training occupations]]

page.title: Programme for the International Assessment of Adult Competencies

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.5)
revision.text:
The '''Programme for the International Assessment of Adult Competencies''' ('''PIAAC''') is a worldwide study by the [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] (OECD) in 24 countries of cognitive and workplace skills. The main aim is to be able to assess the skills of [[literacy]], [[numeracy]] and [[problem solving]] in technology-rich environments, and use the collected information to help countries develop ways to further improve these skills. The focus is on the working-age population (between the ages of 16 and 65). The first data was released on October 8, 2013.<ref>{{cite book|title=OECD Skills Outlook 2013|author=OECD|year=2013|url=http://skills.oecd.org/skillsoutlook.html|ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="thorn2009">{{cite journal | last = Thorn | first = William | title = International Adult Literacy and Basic Skills Surveys in the OECD Region | journal = OECD Education Working Papers | volume = 26 | issue = | pages = | publisher = OECD Publishing | location = | year = 2009 | url = http://www.oecd-ilibrary.org/education/international-adult-literacy-and-basic-skills-surveys-in-the-oecd-region_221351213600 | accessdate = 2013-04-26}} </ref>
==Background== Since the early 1990s the need for assessing literary skills in developed countries has been addressed by two large international surveys. The first was the [[International Adult Literacy Survey]] (IALS) which was implemented in 1994, 1996, and 1998. The second was the [[International Adult Literacy and Life Skills Survey]] carried out in 2003, and between 2006 and 2008.<ref name="nces.ed.gov">http://nces.ed.gov/surveys/all/</ref>
==Basic Skills Assessed== Three central basic skills are assessed in PIAAC: literacy, numeracy and problem solving in technology-rich environments.<ref name="Beatrice Rammstedt, Daniela Ackermann, Susanne Helmschrott, Anja Klaukien, Débora B. Maehler, Silke Martin, Natascha Massing and Anouk Zabal 2013">{{cite book|title=PIAAC 2012: Overview of the Main Results|author1=Beatrice Rammstedt |author2=Daniela Ackermann |author3=Susanne Helmschrott |author4=Anja Klaukien |author5=Débora B. Maehler |author6=Silke Martin |author7=Natascha Massing |author8=Anouk Zabal |year=2013|url=http://www.gesis.org/fileadmin/piaac/Downloadbereich/PIAAC_Zusammenfassung_engl.pdf|ref=harv}}</ref>
===Literacy=== Literacy encompasses the ability to understand, use and interpret written texts. Literacy is a prerequisite for developing one’s knowledge and potential and participating in society. The literacy domain in PIAAC includes tasks such as reading and understanding a drug label or a brief newspaper article. In addition, there are tasks that involve digital media, such as reading an online job posting.
===Numeracy=== Numeracy refers to the ability to access, use and interpret everyday mathematical information in order to manage mathematical demands in daily life. This is measured, for example, with items involving the evaluation of a special offer or the interpretation of numerical information in figures and tables.
===Problem solving in technology-rich environments=== PIAAC is the first international survey to implement problem solving in technology-rich environments ([[Information and Communication Technology|ICT]]). This key skill is defined as the ability to successfully use digital technologies, communication tools and networks to search for, communicate and interpret information. The first wave of PIAAC focuses on how persons access and make use of information in a computer-based environment. Items include sorting and sending e-mails, filling out digital forms, and evaluating the informational content and credibility of different websites.
==Survey Design== PIAAC was initiated by the OECD member states in 2008 and, like PISA, it is designed as a multi-cycle programme. Round 1 took place in 2008-13 (main study in 2011<ref name="nces.ed.gov"/>), supplementary Round 2 in 2012-16, and Round 3 in 2014-18 (main study in 2016-17).<ref>http://www.oecd.org/site/piaac/surveyofadultskills.htm</ref> Subsequent cycles will allow future changes in adult skills to be monitored and analysed and will provide first indications of where improvements have been achieved and deficits persist. Twenty-four countries participated in PIAAC Round I. Nine additional countries also expressed interest in participating in PIAAC. At least 5 000 randomly selected respondents between the ages of 16 and 65 were interviewed and assessed in each participating country. The survey was carried out as a personal interview comprising a questionnaire followed by a skills assessment, a computer- or paper-based version of which was independently completed by the respondent in the presence of the interviewer; the entire interview (including the assessment) took between 1 1/2 and 2 hours to administer.<ref name="Beatrice Rammstedt, Daniela Ackermann, Susanne Helmschrott, Anja Klaukien, Débora B. Maehler, Silke Martin, Natascha Massing and Anouk Zabal 2013"/>
==Results== The results were published in 2013, together with summaries in 25 languages.<ref>{{harvnb|OECD|2013}}</ref>

'''Notes:''' #Sub-national entities (Belgium and UK) are placed at the end followed by two partner countries (Cyprus and Russia) who took part. The figures for Russia are preliminary and do not include Moscow or any items in the 'Missing' category. #Participants were ranked at 5 levels (3 in problem solving). Level 1 corresponds to 176 points. Those who scored less than level 1 are listed above as well as those marked as 'Non-starters' above or 'Missing' in the report, referring to 'literacy-related non-responses' due to mental or learning disabilities or language difficulties. These were marked at 85 (out of 500) in calculating the mean figures. #The last three columns show the extra points scored on average by the first group compared with the second. The last compares native-born native language speakers with foreign-born foreign language speakers. #France, Italy, Spain and Cyprus did not participate in the Problem Solving test, which is officially described as 'Problem Solving in technology-rich environments'. The 'No ICT' column includes those who had no computer experience, opted out or failed a basic IT competence test. #Cyprus only refers to that part under control of the Republic of Cyprus.
===Competence groups=== *Missing: Individuals at this level were unable to complete the background questionnaire. *Below Level 1: can read brief texts on familiar topics and locate a single piece of specific information identical in form to information in the question or directive. *Level 1: (176 points) can complete simple forms, understand basic vocabulary, determine the meaning of sentences, and read continuous texts with a degree of fluency. *Level 2: (226 points) can integrate two or more pieces of information based on criteria, compare and contrast or reason about information and make low-level inferences *Level 3: (276 points) can understand and respond appropriately to dense or lengthy texts, including continuous, non-continuous, mixed, or multiple pages. *Level 4: (326 points) can perform multiple-step operations to integrate, interpret, or synthesise information from complex or lengthy continuous, non-continuous, mixed, or multiple-type texts that involve conditional and/or competing information. *Level 5: (376 points) can perform tasks that involve searching for and integrating information across multiple, dense texts; constructing syntheses of similar and contrasting ideas or points of view, or evaluating evidence and arguments.
For details of the numeracy and ICT tests see {{harvnb|OECD|2013}}.
