[[Category:1981 introductions]] [[Category:Culture of the University of Cambridge]] [[Category:History of the University of Cambridge]] [[Category:University and college rankings]] [[Category:Universities in the United Kingdom]]

A '''varsity match''' is a [[sport|sporting]] fixture between two [[university]] teams, particularly [[University of Oxford|Oxford]] and [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]].{{cite web|url=https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/varsity|title=Varsity|accessdate=23 September 2018|work=Oxford Living Dictionary|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]}} The [[Scottish Varsity]] [[rugby union|rugby]] match between the [[University of St Andrews]] and the [[University of Edinburgh]] at [[Murrayfield Stadium|Murrayfield stadium]] is claimed to be the oldest recurring varsity match in the world, having been played since the 1860s.{{cite news|url=https://www.heraldscotland.com/sport/13214474.World_s_oldest_varsity_match_returns_to_Scotland/|date=19 May 2015|title=World's oldest varsity match returns to Scotland|work=The Herald (Glasgow)}} However, it is predated by the [[The University Match (cricket)|University Match in Cricket]] between Oxford and Cambridge, which was first played in 1827.{{cite web|url=https://www.historychannel.com.au/this-day-in-history/oxford-and-cambridge-play-their-first-cricket-match/|publisher=[[The History Channel]]|title= OXFORD AND CAMBRIDGE PLAY THEIR FIRST CRICKET MATCH: 4 JUNE 1827|accessdate=23 September 2018}} ==Varsity in England== The country's longest-running series of varsity matches is played between the [[University of Cambridge]] and the [[University of Oxford]], dating back, in addition to the 1827 University Match in Cricket mentioned above, to the first "Boat Race" in 1829{{cite web|url=http://www.theboatrace.org/the-basics|title=The Boat Race Basics|publisher=The Boat Race Company Ltd|accessdate=23 September 2018}} and the first "Varsity Match" (in Rugby Union) in 1872.{{cite web|url=http://www.thevarsitymatch.com/about/|title=About – The Varsity Match|publisher=The Varsity Match|accessdate=23 September 2018}} Unusually for British university sporting events, both of these are shown on broadcast television.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00s4wb4|publisher=BBC|title=BBC One – The Boat Race|accessdate=23 September 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://ourfc.org/NewsItem.aspx?ID=2804|title=varsity match returns TO TRADITIONAL HOME ON THE BBC|date=16 July 2015|accessdate=23 September 2018|publisher= Oxford University Rugby Football Club}} Unlike many more recent varsity competitions, the Oxford–Cambridge matches stand alone rather than being part of a wider multi-sport varsity competition. British newspaper ''[[The Independent]]'' proposed in 2008 that [[University of Bath|Bath]] vs [[University of Loughborough| Loughborough]] was "the real varsity match" on the basis that these were the top two teams (at that time) in [[British Universities Sports Association]] (BUSA) competitions.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/education/higher/why-bath-vs-loughborough-is-the-real-varsity-match-845128.html|title=Why Bath vs Loughborough is the real varsity match|author=Richard Garner |date= 12 June 2008|work=The Independent}} Since 2015, [[British Universities and Colleges Sport]] (BUCS), the successor to BUSA, has organised fixtures between Loughborough and [[Durham University|Durham]] (the top two universities since 2011/12) to occur on the same day, in what has been termed the "BUCS Varsity".{{cite web|quote=Durham vs Loughborough on Wednesday 25th November is no ordinary day of University sport. It’s been christened a Varsity and it will have all the hallmarks of one – jam packed, competitive and hectic. However, in truth, it will be so much more than that.
Durham and Loughborough have topped the BUCS Points table every year since 2011/12 and it’s for that reason that the day takes on such significance. It will be a celebration of top-level University sport, crucial in the outcome of this year’s Premiership divisions and a veritable feast of sport for enthusiastic spectators.|url=https://www.bucs.org.uk/news.asp?itemid=19181&itemTitle=Durham%27s+%23BUCSWednesday+breakdown§ion=8§ionTitle=News|title=Durham's #BUCSWednesday breakdown|date= 25 November 2015|author=Matt Roberts|publisher=BUCS}}{{cite news|url=https://www.palatinate.org.uk/clash-of-the-titans-–-durham-vs-loughborough-varsity-preview/|title=Clash of the Titans – Durham vs Loughborough Varsity Preview|date=21 November 2015|author=Simon Carey|work=[[Palatinate (newspaper)|Palatinate]]}} A number of city and regional sporting rivalries exist between universities, which are also dubbed varsity matches. The [[Roses Tournament]] between the universities of [[University of York|York]] and [[University of Lancaster|Lancaster]] is one of the oldest and largest of these, dating back to 1965. It is frequently referred to as the largest inter-university sports tournament in Europe.{{cite news|url=https://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/news/wars-of-the-roses-how-the-rivalry-between-yorkshire-and-lancashire-still-exists-today-1-9170624|work=[[The Yorkshire Post]]|publisher=Johnston Publishing Ltd|title=Wars of the roses: How the rivalry between Yorkshire and Lancashire still exists today|date=18 May 2018|author=Helen Johnson|quote=The sporting rivalry between the two counties has even filtered through to University life, with an annual sporting competition called the ‘Roses Tournament’ existing between University of York and Lancaster University. This tournament began in 1965 and has been described numerous times as the largest inter-university sports tournament in Europe.}} ===Interregional rivalries=== *[[Anglia Ruskin University]] vs [[University of East London]] **Challenge Cup{{cite web|url=https://www.uelunion.org/ents/event/183/|title=UEL Sports Challenge Cup|publisher=UEL Students' Union|accessdate=23 September 2018}} *[[Bath Spa University]] vs [[University of Winchester]] ** Varsity{{cite web|url=https://www.bathspasu.co.uk/events/6013/214/|title=Varsity: Bath Spa vs Winchester|publisher=Bath Spa Students'Union|accessdate=23 September 2018}} *[[Bradford University]] vs [[King's College London]] ** The[[Tolstoy Cup]] *[[Camborne School of Mines]] vs [[Royal School of Mines]] ** The [[Bottle Match]] *[[University of Cambridge]] vs [[University of Oxford]] – every sporting fixture between these two universities can be referred to as a varsity match; the most notable are: **[[The University Match (cricket)|The University Cricket Match]] **[[University Golf Match]] **[[University Match (hockey)|University Hockey Match]] **[[Ice Hockey Varsity Match]] **[[The Varsity Polo Match]] **[[The Boat Race]], the [[Women's Boat Race]] and the [[Henley Boat Races]] - Rowing **[[The Varsity Match]] - Rugby Union **[[Rugby League Varsity Match]] **[[Varsity Trip]] - Skiing **[[The Varsity Yacht Race]] *[[Durham University]] vs [[Loughborough University]] ** [[BUCS]] Varsity{{cite web|url=http://www.bucs.org.uk/news.asp?itemid=16390&itemTitle=%23BUCSwednesday+Focus+on+Loughborough§ion=8§ionTitle=News|title=#BUCSwednesday Focus on Loughborough|date=5 November 2014|accessdate=9 October 2015|publisher=[[BUCS]]}}{{cite news|newspaper=[[Palatinate (newspaper)|Palatinate]]| url=http://www.palatinate.org.uk/?p=62310|date=7 October 2015|first=Simon|last=Carey|accessdate=9 October 2015|title=Want to get involved with sport? The '''Worcester County Mathematics League''' ('''WOCOMAL''') is a [[high school]] [[mathematics]] league composed of 32 high schools, most of which are in [[Worcester County, Massachusetts|Worcester County]], [[Massachusetts]]. It organizes seven mathematics competitions per year, four at the "varsity" level (up to grade 12) and three at the "freshman" level (up to grade nine, including [[middle school]] students). In the 2013-14 school year, WOCOMAL began allowing older students to compete in the freshman level competitions, calling this level of participation "junior varsity."
Top schools from the varsity competition are selected to attend the Massachusetts Association of Math Leagues state competition.
==Contest format==
A competition consists of four, or nine rounds at the Freshman level or five rounds at the Varsity level. The team round consists of eight problems at the Freshman level and nine at the Varsity level. Regardless of level, each student competes in three of the individual rounds.
In each individual round, competing students have ten minutes to answer three questions, worth one, two, and three points. The maximum meet score for a student is eighteen points.
==History== The Worcester County Mathematics League was originally formed in 1963 as the '''Southern Worcester County Mathematics League''' ('''Sowocomal''').<ref>http://www.wocomal.org/coaches/bylaws/196768bylaws.pdf</ref> The winningest school in league history is [[St. John's High School (Massachusetts)|St. John's High School]], with twelve league championships in the fourteen-year span between 1983–84 and 1996-97. [[Algonquin Regional High School]] won six consecutive league championships from 1998-99 to 2003-04.<ref>[http://www.wocomal.org/statistics/varsity/alltime/team/championshipsbyyear.html WOCOMAL All-Time Team Records]</ref>
==Current events== The league currently has members from Western [[Middlesex County, Massachusetts|Middlesex]] Counties. In the past, it has had members from [[Hampshire County, Massachusetts|Hampshire County]], Massachusetts, and [[Windham County, Connecticut|Windham County]], [[Connecticut]].
In the 2015-16 season, the champion of both the varsity division<ref>[http://www.wocomal.org/statistics/varsity/201516/201516v_team.php WOCOMAL Varsity Team Rankings 2015-16]</ref> and the freshman division<ref>[http://www.wocomal.org/statistics/freshman/201516/201516f_team.php WOCOMAL Freshman Team Rankings 2015-16]</ref> was the [[Advanced Math and Science Academy Charter School]].
League members AMSA Charter, [[Worcester Academy]], and [[Mass Academy]] and took first, second, and third place among small-sized schools at the 2016 Massachusetts state championship math meet. St. John's High School took fifth place among medium-sized schools.<ref>[http://www.wocomal.org/statistics/maml/2016/2016m_team.php MAML State Meet Team Rankings 2016]</ref> WOCOMAL schools have taken first place in the state among small schools for thirteen consecutive years.<ref>[http://www.wocomal.org/statistics/maml/alltime/team/championshipsbyyear.php Massachusetts State Championship Math Meet Team Championships by Year]</ref>
At the 2016 New England championship math meet, league members AMSA Charter, Worcester Academy, and Mass Academy took first, second, and fifth place respectively among small schools.<ref>[http://www.wocomal.org/statistics/neaml/2016/2016n_team.php NEAML New England Meet Team Rankings 2016]</ref> WOCOMAL schools have taken first or second place in New England among small schools for twelve consecutive years.<ref>[http://www.wocomal.org/statistics/neaml/alltime/team/championshipsbyyear_s.php New England Championship Math Meet Team Championships by Year (Small)]</ref>

{{italicstitle}} '''''World and I''''' was a monthly magazine owned by [[News World Communications]],<ref name=ann>{{cite news|author=Annys Shin|title=News World Layoffs to Idle 86 Workers|url=https://culteducation.com/group/1277-unification-church/23776-news-world-layoffs-to-idle-86-workers-.html|accessdate=January 15, 2017|work=Washington Post|date=May 3, 2004}}</ref> an international [[news media]] [[corporation]] founded by [[Unification Church]] founder [[Sun Myung Moon]]. ''World and I'' started as a full-color glossy magazine in 1986 as a print magazine published by ''[[The Washington Times]]''. It covered a broad range of articles by scholars and experts in the areas of politics, economics, global studies, liberal arts, fine arts, general science, and books. The magazine ceased publication in 2004.<ref name=ann/>
==''The World and I Online''== The print edition was later replaced by an online publication at the rate of one edition per month. The online publication now called ''The World and I Online'' is headquartered in New York City.
It previously contained [[Spanish language]] pages with articles from ''Tiempos del Mundo'', a now defunct newsweekly published in the United States and in 15 countries of Latin America.
''World and I'' has launched special features for K-12 schools, including core curriculum pages, weekly [[English as a second or foreign language|ESL]] and Spanish pages, teacher’s guide lesson plans. This program on a subscription basis is run through ''World and I School''<ref>[http://www.worldandischool.com/ World and I School website]</ref> and the program ''World and I Kids.<ref>[http://www.worldandischool.com/subscribe/ World and I School page]</ref>''
